Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for the 3rd International Workshop on Software Analytics (SWAN 2017)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The proposal requests funds to support students at the 3rd International Workshop on Software Analytics (SWAN 2017), to take place in September 2017 in Paderborn, Germany. The funds are to encourage US-based students to attend, with priority given to underrepresented groups, US citizens/residents, and those otherwise unable to attend without financial support. The area of software analytics as the basis for empirical research in software engineering leads to a scientific understanding of phenomena surrounding software and its development. The area is emerging and will be boosted by increasing participation in this start-up workshop series. The workshop is a forum for presentation of work in this field, and as such, it will help expand research and strengthen US participation in the field.

Performance_Institution.Name: Florida State University, Department of Computer Science

POR.DRECONTENT:
Five students – two undergraduate and three graduate - from five U.S. universities, spread across five U.S. states were supported through this grant to attend the 3rd International Workshop on Software Analytics (SWAN 2017). Two of the five students supported are part of a minority group: one Hispanic/Latino student, and one student with disabilities. None of the students had attended SWAN before. The grant therefore allowed the increase of student participation in the software analytics research community. Also, three out of the five supported students are U.S. citizens.

The grant covered most of the students’ travel expenses to attend the SWAN 2017 workshop and allowed them to present their papers. The award benefitted the SWAN and software engineering research community at large by allowing the work described in the papers authored by the funded students to be disseminated to the community and by enlarging the SWAN community and its future generation of organizers and researchers (all the students funded had never attended SWAN before). The grant also supported the research community by increasing the participation of minorities in this conference, including students with disabilities and Hispanic/Latino students, as well as the participation of undergraduate students.

The grant contributed towards the training, professional development, and the fostering of professional networks of the supported graduate and undergraduate students by allowing them to attend the research presentations at the workshop and interact with other researchers and practitioners in the field.


Last Modified: 05/16/2018
Modified by: Sonia C Haiduc
